reviewText: I can't say I enjoy the first 13 episodes of this series.  Seems like the writers were finding their way in terms of story telling.  And that dorky theme song!  "Just call for four!  Fantastic four!"  Ug!  The second season's opening theme was alot better because A. no cheesy lyrics, and B. the theme was a bit more dramatic and it felt like you were getting into something a bit more fast paced.  In season 1, I wasn't too keen on Neale Ross's Dr. Doom impersonation.  A bit too much like the terminater, if you ask me.  The man who took over as Doom in season 2 seemed a bit more sinister in his performance.  But Ross is one of my favorite voice actors nonetheless.  He was great in both GI JO and Transformers, and he delivers a mean Green Goblin performance in the 1994 to 98 Spider-man animated series that aired on Fox.I only wish Iron-man and the Incredible Hulk animated series would also be released.  And don't get me started on X-men and Spider-man.  No more of these five episode dvds!  Give us season boxsets!  C'mon, Marvel, you're killing us!  Practicly every show from the DC AU is or soon will be available on dvd, so why can't Marvel fans get what we want as well?Anyway, the series was pretty enjoyable, especially the second season.  So pick it up if you're able.
summary: Not a bad series at all!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I don't know why many studios instist on making Animated series slapstick, as is the case with Season 1 of Fantastic Four.  It's cheesy and corny, and it didn't work out.  Looking to the success of X-Men, Spider-Man, and Batman (which had mature and intelligent dialog and storylines), the Studios decided to change the direction of FF as is evident in Season 2.  It's mature, well-told, and the animation is superb.  Season 1 is fun from a fan's point-of-view, but for non-fans, it's trite, but--as stated--the Box Set is well worth it for Season 2.

reviewText: In short, this is an uneven collection.  It is comprised by 4 discs containing 7, 7, 8, and 4 episodes, respectively, for a total of 26 episodes.  The first disc and the first 6 episodes of the second disc are poorly animated, poorly written and somewhat painful to watch.  Everytime they show the landlady and her dog Fu-Fu I just about hurl.  It is the last episode of the second disc (And A Blind Man Shall Lead Them) where this DVD Collection becomes interesting.  Starting with that episode, the animation and stories become fantastic.  Even the landlady and her dog Fu-Fu are left behind never to be seen again (Thank Goodness!)  The 8 episodes of Disc 3 are a marvel to watch and cover the broad spectrum that characterizes the Fantastic Four comics: from adventures in space, to the micro-verse, and from characters unique to the Fantastic Four (Dr. Doom) to characters that have their own comics (one episode is devoted to The Hulk).  The fourth and final disc contains one weak episode (Hopelessly Impossible) which shows clips of earlier episodes and 3 brilliant episodes including one of the best (Doomsday).  Interestingly, Doomsday was in the back of my mind as I watched  Fantastic Four The Movie which is in theaters now.  In total, there are 12 great episodes.  For me, these 12 masterpieces are worth the price.  Sadly, to fully understand these episodes (unless you are a Fantastic Four aficionado), you have to watch the first 13 episodes on Disc 1 and Disc 2.  A small sacrifice, in my humble opinion.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I’ll be frank.  Half of the episodes on this DVD set are garbage.  Putting nostalgia aside, season 1 of the series comes across as corny, superficially animated, and nonsensical, even after accounting for the age of series.  There is a stark difference between fantasy and believability.  I am willing to believe that the Fantastic Four rode into space and got superpowers.  I am not willing to believe that they did so within a few minutes time span by running to a space shuttle conveniently parked on the top of their apartment building and then launching off with tons of rocket fire shooting down on to New York City rooftops.However, at the start of season 2, everything changes.  The animation becomes markedly better, the directing improves, and the stories become more mature and dramatic.  The finale of the series alone is worth the price of the DVD set and it is one of the best I’ve seen in an animated show.  The grandiloquence of the Silver Surfer and Dr. Doom’s cannot be matched and I have found it a challenge to find a contemporary show whose profoundness of dialogue and sophistication of thought can even offer itself as a contender.  The grandiose of these two men seem almost Shakespearean in the way they comport themselves.This truly remains one of the best written superhero series though there were regrettably very few episodes.  The Thing's comical remarks have survived the test of time as has the playful flirtations between Mr. Fantastic and Susan Storm.  There has not been a Fantastic Four series since that has so appropriately captured the charm and personalities of these beloved comic book characters.I definitely recommend this item for purchase, but suggest skipping right to the episode "And a Blind Man Shall Lead Them" and starting from there.
summary: Still One of the Best Written Superhero Series
Title: N/A

reviewText: Season one was beyond painful.  "Just Call for four, Fantastic Four".  Wow, were they paying homage to Sherward Schwarts of Brady Bunch fame for the theme song?  It seems the producers of the live action movie were greatly inspired by the inspid and campy season one of the Fantastic Four.  It showed in the live action film.Season two is nothing short of brilliant with wonderful animation and terrific storytelling that captured the magic of Lee/Kirby.  My favorite episodes were the Inhumans which even captured identical panels from the original comic on screen, and the series finale featuring the Silver Surfer.  The price is high for what you are getting which is 26 episodes where half are almost unwatchable.  WB does a much fairer pricing system.

reviewText: This along with the 1995 season of Batman and superman adventures are on my DVD Demand list.Ok, first things first, The First season of FF were the worst-EVER! poor jerky animation,lame dialogue and story from Ron Friedman and a chessy opening theme courtesy of Scarface's Georgio Moroder??!!!?? I'm shocked, this guy made a compelling score for the Cult Al Pacino thriller,and Ron Friedman was responsible for the first 2 excellent GI Joe miniseries and Transformers The Movie,ruined the first season of Marvel Comics' first family. I'm sure the late Jack Kirby was spinning in his grave.Now a year later, there's a much improved albiet darker and better version of the FF: Better animation,cooler stories that are slight adaptations of the vintage Stan Lee and Jack Kirby comics and the music fits the series much better. This William Anderson deserves some award of some kind if not a grammy or emmy. (Opening intro deserves a nod as well.)My favorite Lee/Kirby inspired EPS are:Prey of the Black Panther: this cat originaly appeared in FF #50.An honorable african chieftan who dons a sacred garb (with the intellect that rivals Reed Richards and agilities match Captain America's.)takes on the FF and his arch nemises Ulyleses Klaw.Behold a distant star:A family member of Sue and Johnny Storm resurfaces with a shocking past. (very dramatic episode)Doomsday:Dr. Doom (once again) steals the Silver Surfer powers and go on a cosmic power spree with intentions of ruling the world (yeah, and he also plans to end hunger and disease..not bad for someone who is often penned as "Evil".) this episode is crammed with marvel cameos especially the Avengers and a fantastic finale of the series.Pros:Great seacond season: Nuff SaidStory continuity: from Doom Still angry about what Ben Grimm did to his hand,to Johnny's Quest (no pun intended) to find crystal.Cons:The box set also includes the first seasonPoor Menu interface with techno music. LMaoooNo extras (sorry, but stan lee's introductions don't qualify for being extras.)My suggestion..get the box set but sell the first season.where's the Hanna Barbera box set?!!??
summary: I'll give it a "Fantastic " Four Stars
Title: N/A

reviewText: I found this used like new for $8.00, so it's hard to complain. The show ran two seasons and fortunately was retooled for the second season. The first season is not all that good, but not a total disaster. The worst thing about this set is that there are no chapter breaks. Which means you must sit through that awful theme song time and time again (I fast forwarded through it after the first episode). On the plus side, the theme song was removed after season one and season two has a new improved intro. It would have been nice if there were some bonus material on this release, but there is nothing worth listing here.Season one is very juvenile, I know it's a kids show, but there are many super hero cartoons that aren't this corny and the animation is pretty bland. It does get better as the season goes along with appearences by Sub Mariner and The Super Skull.Season two is where if really takes off. Better animation and stories with guest appearances from Daredevil, The Hulk, Thor, The Silver Surfer, The Inhumans and Ghost Rider. Of course the FF's main villains are here Dr Doom, The Mole Man and Galactus to name a few. There are a few very brief cameos by The Vision, Hercules, She Hulk, Iron Man, Captain America and The Scarlet Spider.If your a fan of the series then you will want to pick this up, but I can't see paying $40 to $50 for this though. It's easy to find for under $10. All 26 episodes on four picture discs, each featuring one of the 4 team members. The only extras are introductions by Stan Lee which are well....you know Stan!....ZZZZzzzzzzzz.Overall the series is pretty good, but I prefer 60's Spider-Man and DC Filmation to this stuff. Although season two is a huge improvement and really quite good. This series just doesn't hold the magic of the earlier stuff for me, probably because I grew up watching the early ones. If you grew up in the 90's then I'm sure this is more nostalgic for you. If they had added chapter breaks and added a few extras I would have given this another star, but this is a lazy release that should have been better.
summary: LACKLUSTER RELEASE BUT WORTH IT FOR FANS!

reviewText: First off, be aware that the first season of this show is AWFUL! Terrible animation and lackluster action. The actors doing the voices are great though, but the cartoon is still very, very difficult to watch. HOWEVER, the second season is quite terrific! The animation and designs greatly improved, as did the use of the characters' powers, especially Invisible Woman and Mr. Fantastic. The same actors did the voices, with the exception of Human Torch, but the scripts were much better than the first season. If the first season of this series would have been as high-quality as the second season, this show probably would have lasted longer than it did. I suspect many fans gave up during the dreadful first season.
summary: Get it for the second season!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This bty far was one of my favorite animated series (along with superman and batman adventures)of the mid 90's.I never really cared much for the X-men  or Spiderman cartoons, but the FF was an unexepected surprise. After the the horrible poorly animated 1994 season, i was very skeptical of FF's second run. but when i saw the thing take on  a few of Dr. Doom's Robots,let alone better animation and an appearance of Daredevil, from then on me and my friends were hooked every sunday morning.the first season is insignificant, thus here's my take on the remaining DVDs;the series has vastly improved, with cool stories that pay homage to the Stan Lee Jack Kirby era, the Music and theme fit the series very well accompanied by great voice acting. especially  Dr. Doom's.Most of the venerable second season episodes were filled with cameos courtesy of other marvel characters; Inhumans,the Incredible Hulk,Black Panther, (the first black superhero of all comicdom,.)Thor,Ghost Rider and even a glimpse of Captain America and the avengers. (see Doomsday) The sad thing is just when Marvel got it right, the FF's second season was it's last.Doomsday was the fitting swan song of the series.As for the DVD set, there are no extras, and the Menu has annoying Techno Music.....WTF does techno has to do with the Fantastic Four?!? Stan's soapbox/introduction of each episode was short and had a "been there,done that feel" but hey, he's the Man. What's cool is each episodes title card has an illustration of the FF from the late great Jack Kirby. the undisputed archietect of Marvel Comics!!I will savor these disc 4 a loonnnggg time.

reviewText: Mainly put together and released as part of a marketing ploy to coincide with the release of the big budget movie this summer, this box set of the Fantastic Four animated series that ran during the mid-90's has it's share of good and bad.  The first few episodes of the first season are what makes up the bad part of this box set, featuring some choppy animation, laughable dialogue, and some cheesy storytelling.  When the series got re-tooled, it took off and was far more reminiscent of the classic comic stories from various runs by Stan Lee, Jack Kirby, John Byrne, and such.  There are guest heroes and villains galore, including the Puppet Master, the Silver Surfer, Thor, the Hulk, Daredevil, and even Ghost Rider.  This box set is worth owning for die hard FF fans, but it may be a bit too pricy for some.  Hopefully with the release of this box set, maybe season box sets of Fox's X-Men animated series from the 90's will be released as well.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of those rare boxed sets that I had been savoring for quite some time. It turns out that I somehow managed to completely overlook this series when it was originally syndicated for broadcast television- probably on account of Batman and X-Men The Animated Series' which ran at the same time.To clear the air, I've always had a bit of difficulty with the Fantastic Four source material, feeling that it had aged much less gracefully than some of the other comic stories that had spawned around the same time (in some cases, even earlier).  I had never fully grasped why the solar radiation that bombarded the spacecraft had affected each of the crew members' DNA in such diverse means.  Mutations I can understand, but the net result of the exposure had absolutely nothing in common with how it affected a person seated a mere foot away.  Add to this names like Mr. Fantastic and the Fantastic-car and it doesn't take long to realize that Marvel has their hands full in this day and age with trying to represent a much more innocent era of human society to one that is far more jaded.  But I digress, this is comic animation after all so let us put aside such technicalities and focus on the two-season boxed set at hand.Regardless of how you view the team itself, the opening credits to the first season will recreate the group's origins through a cheesy pop jingle that will cause even the most diehard FF fans to question their devotion. Once the credits fade and the program begins, there is little in the way of an improvement to report. The plot execution and character development are simply terrible throughout the first two discs.For whatever reason the animation is choppy and primitive paling even to its sister series, X-Men which began a full two years earlier.  What's worse is that like Superfriends which aired a full two decades earlier, the first season of the Fantastic Four is riddled with ridiculous dialogue and cliché sound effects. Many times characters will over-explain themselves to the audience in dialog like "The impact has made me become visible. I must find a way out." Or villains will talk us through their world dominating schemes in step by step simplification. The story plots are sloppy and full of laughable situations. This isn't to suggest that it's impossible to sit through all thirteen episodes but be forewarned that the delivery here is best viewed with very low expectations.Fortunately, discs 3 & 4 of the boxed set switch gears dramatically as the second (1995) season had gone through a complete retooling which included a new host of creative and development staff, improved animation, and even a new theme song.  The animation itself was vastly improved to levels witnessed with other leading animated series' of the time. The character designs were also crafted to darker outfit motifs with more subtle voice work. The new opening credits are a vast improvement in their own right; providing a more epic feel to the whole concept. The show's writers were also wise to adapt plots right from the pages of the original Stan Lee/ Jack Kirby comics. Apparently the FF's originators knew well what worked and what didn't when laying out scenarios with their team.The second season also does a nice job of incorporating a host of cameos in the form of both heroes and villains: Daredevil, Scarlet Spider, Ghostrider, The Hulk, and the X-Men all make appearances (just to name a few).Sadly, however, is that this set comes to us from Buena Vista which immediately means a few nagging complaints.  The first of which is that the set is basically completely devoid of features or extras.  There are several-second intros read by Stan Lee himself before each episode but the effect is pretty lackluster in action. Other than that, zero, zip, zilch as far as extras are concerned.  Also Buena Vista is known for its poor menu design.  Fantastic Four is no exception with cobby navigation and a completely out of place sound score.  Finally paying near $35 to own this set doesn't earn us immunity from Disney's promotional efforts as the set begins with some previews for other Disney films and DVDs (which thankfully can be skipped over with a well timed button press).The episodes are presented in their original full-frame aspect ratio with no pixelation, edge enhancement, or other common transfer flaws. And like the video, the sound is crisp and clear, with the Dolby Digital 2.0 surround treatment to boot.Overall this is a difficult series to rate. Season One earns a 2.5 score, Season Two deserves at least a 4 star rating, and the set itself, although beautifully packaged, earns a solid 3 for lack of extras and poor menu work.  Since Amazon doesn't allow a score of 3.5 stars, I will round up to a 4 overall. Included on this set are the following:Season OneThe Origin of the Fantastic Four, Part OneThe Origin of the Fantastic Four, Part TwoIncursion of the SkrullsNow Comes the Sub-MarinerThe Silver Surfer & the Coming of Galactus, Part OneThe Silver Surfer & the Coming of Galactus, Part TwoSuperskrullThe Mask of Doom, Part OneThe Mask of Doom, Part TwoThe Mask of Doom, Part ThreeThe Silver Surfer and the Return of GalactusMole ManBehold the Negative ZoneSeason TwoAnd a Blind Man Shall Lead ThemInhumans Saga, Part One: And the Wind Cries MedusaInhumans Saga, Par Two: The Inhumans Among UsInhumans Saga, Part Three: Beware the Hidden LandWorlds Within WorldsTo Battle the Living PlanetPrey of the Black PantherWhen Calls GalactusNightmare in GreenBehold, a Distant StarHopelessly ImpossibleThe Sentry SinisterDoomsday
Title: N/A

reviewText: Marvel changed comics for the better with the Fantastic Four.  It was only the beginning of what remains my favorite comics ever (while they were good).  Sadly, the FF jumped the shark not when Alicia broke up with Ben & married Johnny Storm (that was a very interesting twist), but when it was revealed that what he actually married was a Skrull.  But the first three hundred & fifty-something issues are still gold.  Time will never tarnish them.  What does this have to do with the series?  Nothing, it's just my opinion of the original comic.  Now let's get to the review.Just like the Iron Man cartoon, this show had a bad first season.  Unlike Iron Man's first season, there is nary a decent episode to be found.  The animation is even worse than in Iron Man (it's so bad I think the 60s cartoon looks better), and the dialogue more painful despite a lot of it being directly translated from the comics.  But like Iron Man, the second season came along & was vastly superior.  In my opinion it was the best adaption of the four in blue ever, much better than the movies (I pray that comparing the future FF remake to the movies out now will be like comparing the second season of this show to the first season).  Even 6-year old me could've told you the show improved.  So skip disc 1, & jump straight to the end of disc 2 & proceed from thereon with (NOTE: the synopsizes come from Marvel Animation Age & Wikipedia):14.  And the Blind Man shall Lead Them:  Doctor Doom explodes a nuclear device which causes the Four to lose their super powers.  This is the perfect episode to start the truly fantastic second season, especially since Daredevil guest stars (he's one of my favorite Marvel characters).  A+15.  The Inhuman Saga, Part One:  The Fantastic Four find themselves up against The Frightful Four: The Wizard, The Trapster, Hydro-Man & Medusa.  The Fantastic Four really meet their match in this excellent episode.  A+16.  The Inhuman Saga, Part Two:  When Johnny forces Medusa out of New York, he discovers a race of Inhumans who live beneath a deserted part of the city, and The Four find themselves facing them.  The second worst episode of the season.  While for the most part it's great, the Johnny/Krystal romance feels rushed.  A-17.  The Inhuman Saga, Part Three:  The Fantastic Four battle the evil Inhumans and their leader, Maximus the Mad, to foil their plan to destroy the human world.  This is an excellent ending to a mostly great 3 part story.  A+18.  Worlds Within Worlds:  Psycho-Man, ruler of another dimension, attacks The Fantastic Four by using psychological weapons.  A great adaption of one of the cooler FF villains. A+19.  To Battle The Living Planet:  A mysterious gravitational pull from outer space causes major disasters around the world, and The Fantastic Four must team up with Galactus to fight the planet Ego.  An especially good episode, thanks in no small part to Thor's guest appearance.  A+20.  Prey of the Black Panther:  An intruder called the Black Panther lures the Fantastic Four into an African steel jungle. The Pather reveals himself as the Chieftain of the Wakanda tribe who needs help to defeat Ulysses Klaw.  The Black Panther is another one of most favorite Marvel characters, & his appearance here was perfect, especially his voice (Keith David, who voiced Goliath on Gargoyles).  A+21.  When Calls Galactus:  A girl called Frankie is revealed to have powers identical to Johnny's. Terrax attacks the city and demands the Fantastic Four face Galactus once more, but they discover Terrax double-crossed Galactus and fight him.  Another truly fantastic episode.  A+22. Nightmare in Green:  On a night with Alicia, Ben fights the Hulk until Alicia asks him to stop. Dr. Doom takes the opportunity to trick the Hulk into crushing the Fantastic Four.  I love all of the season 2 episodes with Doctor Doom in them, & the Hulk just makes this even better.  A+23.  Behold, a Distant Star:  Another failed invasion of the Skrulls gets Sue into a coma, saved by her and Johnny's father Dr. Storm, who is marked as a murderer. Meanwhile the Super-Skrull returns in Storm's appearance for a second attack on the Fantastic Four.  This is one of my top 5 episodes because it contains stuff you'll almost never see on cartoons these days.  A+24.  Hopelessly Impossible:  A strange person called Impossible Man goes inside the Fantastic Four's HQ only to find the building vacant. He reads about their past adventures, whilst the Super-Skrull lingers.  A clip show, but unlike the Iron Man episode, the framing device is really good.  Jess Harnell (the voice of Wakko in Animaniacs) perfectly brought the Impossible Man to life, who is definitely one of Marvel's funniest characters.  C+25.  The Sentry Sinister:  As the Fantastic Four go to Tee Vu Island (leaving Johnny behind) where a spaceport is guarded by a strong sentry.  A great episode.  A26.  Doomsday:  Dr. Doom steals the Silver Surfer's cosmic force and just might succeed in controlling the world.  Like Iron Man, this series ends on its best episode.  A+It's a tragedy this show didn't continue.  Any Fantastic Four fan should have this in their collection, & I definitely recommend this to you if you enjoyed the movies.  Just remember- skip to the last episode on Disc 2 proceed from then on.  Everything before that is bad.  I give it 5 stars because I got it for $10, so that's a dollar for every A+ episode, with 3 other watchable ones for free.  A great deal if you ask me.
summary: Marvel's first family in their greatest onscreen adventures.

reviewText: A lot of the critics agree that the first season wasn't the best.  It did have some guest star voices, never to be seen again. The second year was a vast improvement over the first. I only wish it could have gone on to more seasons.  Where else can you hear voices of the late great Dick Clark (as himself), Gary Owens and much more.  I never thought they would think twice to voice a Fantastic Four cartoon. However, it does have the spirit of the comics and it's a series you can watch over and over again.
summary: Fantastic cartoon that adapts the original comics!

reviewText: For one thing, I didn't know there was a 90's version of the Fantastic Four cartoon series.  This is not the one I wanted when I ordered this a a few months ago. I am now finally able to see it and low and behold, I am disappointed.  I expected the original cartoon series which is still shown on tv today, not this modernized version. I don't mean to sound too critical but I am not into these modernized, newer versions of these classic cartoons. The batman, superman,  justice league, etc. are not the ones I grew up on. I watched a few minutes of a few of the Fantastic Four episodes and I am not too thrilled.  They are ok, so I guess I may have to watch them more so they can grow on me, but I am really waiting for the old Fantastic Four cartoon to come out on DVD.  Anyone know if and when that will happen?
summary: Not the cartoon series I wanted

Title: N/A

reviewText: Marvel had to follow DC and WB's success with BATMAN, and this was the best they could do. The first season was a bit weak, mostly because the episodes were adaptations of the classic Stan Lee/Jack Kirby stories, mostly by screenwriter Ron Friedman of G.I. JOE fame. I only wish this was done in the mid 1980s, because that's where most of the dialogue belonged.The second season was a great improvement, moreso because of a revolving door of screenwriters. Even though the stories were still adaptations of works by Lee and Kirby, the staff managed to adapt three stories from John Byrne's run, which gave it some depth. The voice acting was on point.Although now there's an anime-esque FF series on the Cartoon Network now, I still prefer both this set and the 1967-68 Hanna-Barbera animated FF as their best outings in animation. I hope the 1960s FF and SPIDER-MAN & HIS AMAZING FRIENDS will be collected on DVD anytime soon in the near future. The same for IRON MAN, SPIDER-MAN (1980s solo and 1990s solo series), the HULK and X-MEN/X-MEN: EVOLUTION. I can't forget the SILVER SURFER series, too.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Fantastic Four Boxed DVD Set may be a tad pricey but it sure is worth it for the Season 2 DVDs alone. This season of the Cartoon originally titled "Marvel Action Hour then Retitled "Marvel action Universe came packaged with an Iron Man Cartoon on Sunday Mornings in syndication.While the first season episodes are terrible, (You have been warned) the second season of the cartoon has great animation and amazing story adaptations that captures the spirit of Stan Lee and Jack Kirby's comics. It even touched on storylines featuring the John Byrne Run of the Fantastic four. Guest stars include the incredible Hulk, The Black Panther (Strongly Voiced By Keith David of Gargoyles) Daredevil (an enthusiastic Bill Simtrovich) Thor, (voiced by an amazing John-Rhys-Davies) The Silver Surfer, The inhumans and The Frightful Four and of course Doctor Doom. Cameos include Ghost Rider, Iron man and the Avengers. If you're into the Marvel Universe, you'll spot about a dozen more heroes in passing frames like the X-men, Scarlet spider and even the Juggernaut!I own all the second season episodes on tape (they were that good I started collecting them) and I love watching them until the audio gave out. Now that they're on DVD I'm going to upgrade just to get these second season episodes on disc. These are great fun for the kids who love superheroes like Spider-man, X-men and the justice league.
summary: Worth purchasing for the Second Season alone Enjoy!

reviewText: In the mid-90's many of Marvel's characters came to the small screen on Saturday mornings after the success of X-men and Spiderman.  One of those was Marvel's very first group of Superheroes, the Fantastic Four.  With the movie due to come out in a few weeks, it's great to have these episodes on DVD finally.  The set contains all 26 episodes of the run.  While I agree that the first season (And I have them on VHS because I am a geek) was inferior to the second season, the first season is not without its merits, mainly in the presentation of the group's origin as well as the two part "Silver Surfer and the Coming of Galactus" episode.  This is one of the key moments in Marvel's silver age history and I thought they did a very nice job with it.  I also enjoyed the Behold the Negative Zone episode as I loved the goofy villains Annihilus and Blaastar.Things do pick up in season two in 1995 with several outstanding episodes including:The Three part Inhumans Saga where the FF battle the Frightful Four and then eventually travel to the hidden Great Refuge of the Inhumans.To Battle the Living Planet - The FF enlist the Aid of Galactus to battle Ego, the Living Planet, but at what price?  Thor co-stars.When Calls Galactus - Galactus is back to devour the earth and only the sacrifice of Frankie Raye saves the earth as she becomes his new herald named Nova.Nightmare in Green - The Thing battles the Hulk!  Nuff said!Doomsday is an adaption of one of my favorite stories as Dr. Doom captures the Silver Surfer and steals his power to battle the FF.While the animation on the Fantastic Four wasn't quite as good as Spiderman or the X-men, it was still pretty good and the show really seemed to be hitting its stride when it ended after just two seasons.  And of course this is vastly superior to the two earlier cartoon versions of the 60's and 70's.  Herbie the robot anyone?
summary: NOT ON A PAR WITH SPIDERMAN BUT STILL GOOD
Title: N/A

reviewText: First off I want to tell you the production of this set is excellent, it has a real cool "official" look to it like some marvel high ranking exc. Took you down a long hallway to a safe opened it up and said "check this out!!" The picture of this set doesn't do it justice, from the slip case to the fold out section where the four disc are kept this set just looks really cool! I keep it on a shelf in my entertainment center behind glass for all to see and sure enough everyone who sees it says that is cool as hell, where did you get it! The only drawback is it is made of a cardboard stock that is not strong or heavy enough to keep the set safe for some serious years, as a collector I can guarantee that when this is no longer in print it will be worth some serious $cash$ because it is marvel, (if you care about that sort of thing) the reason I bought this is because I love all things marvel comics and animation, each episode is shown in it's original format and order the animation is nice and crisp (although you can tell it was made in the 90's) and stands up to the test of time, sound quality is excellent even on high end flat screen TV's, the first season is rather corny you will grow to hate the theme song, the meat of this series is in the second season where everything was revamped even the theme song this is where the best episodes are, best thing about this set is the fact that you get to see the FF at it's beginning and all the classic villains the skrulls,galactus and the silver surfer, prince Namor, Dr. Doom and the mole man! All in the first season! I would recommend this to any marvel fan or anyone who wants to jump on the FF bandwagon as this is good for the whole family NUFF' SAID!!

reviewText: This version was ok, especially if one is an FF fanatic like myself.  However, I agree with another reviewer.  We want the 1960's cartoon series!  It was the best of the three.  I cannot decide if the 2nd or the 3rd versions come next.  This one here is the 3rd FF cartoon series.  As I recall, the 2nd version did not conatin the Torch, as he was replaced by Herbie the Robot.  Hence, this version I would probably rate as 2nd best of the three.
summary: 1960's version was the best of the three FF cartoon series
